overview: Sydney is just the beginning of an amazing adventure in Australia and New Zealand, renowned for their spectacular wildlife around the city. While Sydney and other cities in Australia and New Zealand offer fantastic dining and experiences, they generally have a more relaxed vibe compared to the hustle and bustle of New York City or LA. Here's a guide to help you make the most of your stay in Sydney and explore its natural wonders.

activities.name: Bondi Beach to Coogee Beach Walk
highlights: Chill at any beach along the way!
Shop at Bondi Junction on the way to or from Bondi Beach

activities.name: Ferry to Taronga Zoo
highlights: The ferry is nice, but for the zoo stay close to the exit if you want to hop on the shuttle as soon as possible

activities.name: Ferry to Manly Beach
highlights: Snorkel along the way and at Shelley Beach

activities.name: Party boat around Sydney Harbour
highlights: Or ask me and we can rent a boat, I'll be your skipper ðŸ™‚

activities.name: SEA LIFE Sydney Aquarium and Australian National Maritime Museum
Kamay Botany Bay National Park, Cronulla Beach and Sand Dunes, Kurnell Beach

locations.name: Bar Totti's
locations.blurb: Antipasto and crab pasta are must-tries. Book a table in advance.

locations.name: Mango Coco
locations.blurb: Renowned for desserts like Egg on Nest. Worth a visit for a sweet treat.

locations.name: Spicy Joint
locations.blurb: Perfect for those who love a good Mala/Szechuan spice experience.

locations.name: Mr. Wong
locations.blurb: Upscale, modern Asian cuisine with a stylish ambiance.

locations.name: Hansang
locations.blurb: Traditional Korean dishes in a cozy setting; known for their hearty soup.

locations.name: Bornga
locations.blurb: Classic Korean BBQ with quality meats.

locations.name: Gogo Music BBQ
locations.blurb: Casual Japanese dining with a varied menu.

locations.name: Abura Soba Noodles
locations.blurb: Delicious soba noodle dishes in a simple, no-fuss environment.

locations.name: Mensho Ramen
locations.blurb: Authentic ramen with rich, flavorful broths.

locations.name: Beom Beom
locations.blurb: Modern Korean fusion with a creative twist.

locations.name: HeyTea
locations.blurb: Popular tea spot known for cheese teas; also available in Burwood and Melbourne CBD.

locations.name: Bengong Metro
locations.blurb: Contemporary dessert and pastry shop with a chic vibe.

locations.name: The Eight
locations.blurb: Dim Sum.

locations.name: Ho Jiak
locations.blurb: Malaysian cuisine.

locations.name: Holy Basil
locations.blurb: Thai cuisine.

locations.name: Kuki Soft Serve and Cookies
locations.blurb: Soft serve and cookies.

locations.name: Thanon Khaosan
locations.blurb: Thai cuisine.

locations.name: Betty's Burgers
locations.blurb: Classic burgers with a cult following.

locations.name: Doodee King
locations.blurb: Thai street food with bold flavors.

locations.name: A Bowl of Noodles
locations.blurb: Shanghai-style noodles; scallion oil noodles are a must-try.

locations.name: Cantina OK!
locations.blurb: Renowned for its margaritas.

locations.name: Bancho
locations.blurb: Asian-inspired cocktails with unique flavors.

locations.name: Vina Bar
locations.blurb: Viet-inspired cocktails.

suburbs.name: Surry Hills
suburbs.blurb: Yuppie food, perfect spot for brunch or trendy modern meals.

locations.name: Paramount Coffee Projects
locations.blurb: Excellent brunch spot with a trendy atmosphere.

locations.name: AP Bakery
locations.blurb: Grab some delicious pastries to-go; take the elevator upstairs.

locations.name: Ito
locations.blurb: Japanese-inspired dishes with a minimalist approach.

locations.name: JIBBICOFFEE ROASTERS
locations.blurb: World-class coffee: won the World AeroPress Championship and more.

locations.name: Azuki Bakery
locations.blurb: Small bakery with tasty treats.

locations.name: Maeda
locations.blurb: Japanese cuisine with a relaxed atmosphere.

locations.name: Hanoi on King Newtown
locations.blurb: Vietnamese joint.

locations.name: Thai Pothong
locations.blurb: Decent Thai food, nothing exceptional.

locations.name: Mr. Stonebowl
locations.blurb: Popular Chinese restaurant with a wide range of dishes.

locations.name: Xi Bay Hand Made Noodles
locations.blurb: Delicious handmade noodles; a must-try.

locations.name: Tea n Co
locations.blurb: Cozy spot for tea and light snacks.

locations.name: HeyTea
locations.blurb: Famous for cheese teas; also available in CBD and Melbourne.

locations.name: Bengong Bakery
locations.blurb: Known for pastries and boba. The Town Hall and Darling Harbour locations offer different selections.

locations.name: Karriton Dessert
locations.blurb: Ube-flavored sweet bread. If you're heading to Melbourne, consider getting it there in the CBD.

locations.name: Homeway
locations.blurb: Shandong food.

locations.name: Mandoo
locations.blurb: Phenomenal dumplings and hearty soups. Perfect for sharingâ€”order one soup and a couple of dumplings for two.

locations.name: Hansang
locations.blurb: Reliable spot for traditional Korean cuisine.

locations.name: Jongro Hwaro KBBQ
locations.blurb: Highly recommended; our top KBBQ in Sydney. Let us know if you agree!

locations.name: Butcherant KBBQ
locations.blurb: Another top pick for quality KBBQ.

locations.name: Myeongdong
locations.blurb: Tasty Korean dishes in a casual setting.

suburbs.name: Marrickville
suburbs.blurb: Vietnamese suburb, but trendy eats and cafes.

locations.name: Vn Street Food
locations.blurb: Worth the trip for exceptional bun cha. Order at the counter, eat on the other side, and don't forget to grab spices for dipping your meat.

locations.name: Jasmine 1
locations.blurb: Lebanese in Leichardt.

locations.name: Bondi Junction
locations.blurb: Great for food and shopping.

suburbs.name: The Grounds of Alexandria
suburbs.blurb: A charming 'plaza' close to our home, ideal for a quick visit. Though it's a popular Instagram spot, there's not much else going on.

suburbs.name: My Mother's Cousin (Bexley North)
suburbs.blurb: Excellent pizza and hot honey wings, with a standout apple pie ice cream dessert. Perfect for a satisfying meal.

tips.heading: Cash and Cards
tips.details: You usually won't need cash; your travel card will suffice. While most places accept cards, a few Asian restaurants might be cash-only. If you need cash, just let me know, and I can help.

tips.heading: Tipping
tips.details: Tipping isn't customary in Australia. If a place prompts for a tip, you can simply select 'No tip'. Some restaurants are starting to include tipping to increase their revenue, but it's not the norm.

tips.heading: Sun Protection
tips.details: The Australian sun is intense due to the ozone layer's thinning. Be sure to apply sunscreen every 4 hours to protect your skin.

tips.heading: Snorkeling Gear
tips.details: We have snorkeling gear for you to borrow if you're interested in exploring underwater.

tips.heading: Public Transport
tips.details: Sydney's public transport within the city is efficient and convenient. You can use your debit or credit card, Apple Pay, or Google Pay to tap on and off buses, trains, and ferries.

tips.heading: Car Rental
tips.details: If you need a car, let me know. We can arrange for you to use my [GoGet](https://www.goget.com.au/), which is often cheaper than Uber Carshare (discontinued as of 12 September 2024) or traditional car rentals. Remember, Australians drive on the left side of the road, so please drive carefully!

tips.heading: Airport Transport
tips.details: Avoid taking the train between the airport and the city; it's quite expensive at $25-35 per person. Avoid taxis too, as they can be pricey, especially if they think you're a touristâ€”they may charge a higher rate. For groups, it's often more economical to take an Uber or DiDi. During non-peak times, an Uber might cost around $35-$40, which is reasonable if split among two or more people. During peak times, prices can soar to $60-$80, but check DiDi as their prices are typically cheaper, and walk to the pickup point.
